reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of Essential Chronic Disease Medication to 13,389 Elderly Palestinian Refugees (PRL PRS) in Lebanon's Camps and Gatherings

description.narrative:
The Project will provide essential chronic medicines to elderly (60 years and older) Palestinian Refugees in Lebanon (PRS and PRL) in close collaboration with UNRWA.
Anera will extend a critical lifeline to PRL and PRS by addressing urgent health needs for over 13,389 older persons throughout Lebanon, specifically to address some of the most prevalent chronic disease conditions among elderly PRL and PRS, namely, diabetes, hypertension and other cardiovascular diseases.
The intervention will concentrate on provision of essential medications to these vulnerable populations requiring tailored support, ensuring that the medications are in line with UNRWA Lebanon's essential drug list and are properly managed and dispensed to eligible beneficiaries.
This project will ensure that UNRWA has an adequate supply of essential medicines to cover the needs of PRS and PRL with these chronic illnesses. This will be ensured through local purchase of priority medicines supplemented by additional provision from Anera’s own in-kind program. Since 1968, Anera’s in-kind program has distributed millions of dollars’ worth of medicines for chronic conditions, hospital equipment, wheelchairs, over-the-counter drugs, and health care supplies that would not otherwise be available in the communities where they are needed the most. Our deliveries support hospitals, clinics, schools, and community centers struggling to meet the needs of underprivileged families. For example, Anera has organized shipments of antibiotics for winter illnesses in hard-to-reach areas of Mount Lebanon has delivered dialysis units, gauze rolls, syringes, cotton rolls, and blood filters for Palestinian Refugees in Rashidiyyeh Camp and facilitated diabetes medications for Dar Al Ajaza Hospital in Beirut. Anera will use this experience to bring further resources to PRS and PRL in Lebanon, avoiding a rupture of stock and break in their treatment in order to keep their health condition under proper medical management. Currently, PRS and PRL are the most vulnerable of refugees in Lebanon—with the least resiliency and the least access to humanitarian assistance. They are unable to pay for essential medications with their own resources and thus are highly vulnerable should a rupture of stock occur.
Anera's programs and services reach out to all Palestinian refugee camps and gatherings around Lebanon through its six offices in different governorates, including inside Ein Helwe camp in Saida. It employs over 60 local staff who are experienced in various sectors, and outreach volunteers who will be utilized to support this project and ensure its proper implementation and monitoring, including access to target beneficiaries, compliance to good pharmacy practices, and overall beneficiary satisfaction with the project.
Anera will target approximately 13,389 PRS and PRL hypertension or diabetes patients (7,900 women 5,489 men) .
